awd_titl_txt: CAREER: System-on-Cloth: A Cloud Manufacturing Framework for Embroidered Wearable Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award will contribute to the advancement of national prosperity and economic welfare by researching systems that improve access to manufacturing services.  Wearable electronics are widely used in health monitoring and wearable computing and there is a compelling need for comfort, biocompatibility, and easy operation. Recent progress in smart fabrics, textiles, and garments and the associated manufacturing technologies provides opportunities for next-generation wearable electronic devices that are fabricated on cloth. Automatic embroidery manufacturing is now an accessible tool for individuals and entrepreneurs. Embroidery offers great potential for electronic design due to its flexibility in transferring a desired pattern to fabric substrates. This project aims to establish a cloud manufacturing framework that integrates electronics and design-to-manufacturing translation in a system that can be used by customers, manufacturers, design experts, and developers to design and produce embroidered wearable electronics. In addition, this project also aims to broaden participation from K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students, to provide rich multidisciplinary classroom and non-classroom experiences for all levels of students, and to inspire student interest in STEM careers.

The research goal of this CAREER project is to establish a cloud-based manufacturing framework for embroidered wearable electronics as an accessible platform technology towards System-on-Cloth. Three tasks are planned to achieve the goal: 1) to understand physical variations of conductive threads and flexible electronics by physical modeling and experimental testing for embroidered electronics; 2) to create Electronic Design Automation (EDA) software that will realize design-to-manufacturing translation from schematics by integrating new Electrical Rule Checking (ERC) and Design Rule Checking (DRC) criteria, optimal stitch generation, and an open library of wearable electronics; and 3) to explore a cloud manufacturing framework with open architecture, open source code, and friendly user-interfaces that is accessible to customers, manufacturers, software developers, as well as electronic design experts. The cloud manufacturing framework will incorporate EDA features, high tractability, reliability, and compatibility for use by a diverse spectrum of individuals and entrepreneurs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Wearable electronics are widely used in health monitoring, well-being management, and human-robot interaction, and there is a compelling need for comfort, biocompatibility, and easy operation in people’s daily living. Recent progress in smart fabrics, textiles, and garments and the associated manufacturing technologies provides opportunities for next-generation wearable devices that are fabricated on cloth. Embroidery offers great potential for electronic design due to its flexibility in transferring a desired pattern to fabric substrates. In this project, we have developed a cloud manufacturing (CMfg) framework for embroidered electronics as an accessible platform technology towards System-on-Cloth (SoCl). This platform technology integrates electronics and design-to-manufacturing translation and can be used by developers, manufacturers, design experts, as well as the general public to design and fabricate embroidered electronics on clothes to achieve different functions. The ultimate goal is that everyone can design their own desired wearable devices on clothes through our platform.

We believe our embroidered electronics technology towards SoCl will lead to paradigm-shifting progress in wearable electronics. The major outcomes are fourfold: 1) A open-source platform and network for tractable, reliable, automatic design-to-manufacturing translation for embroidered wearable electronics has been developed and successfully deployed, which is publicly accessible and thus everyone can design wearable electronics on cloth for various applications at low cost; 2) this framework is established with open source code, open architecture, and open knowledge to facilitate the development of the CMfg technique as well as SoCl; 3) a number of functional embroidered electronics have been developed and deployed to the platform, and end users can register and download freely to embroider to their own clothes;  and 4) an open source ecosystem for embroidered electronics is being formed towards a sustainable technology for enabling new embroidered electronics in different domains. The education objectives of this project are to broaden participants from K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students, provide rich multidisciplinary classroom and non-classroom experiences for all levels of students, and inspire students’ interests in a STEM career. The research products have been disseminated to a broader audience through workshops and special sessions at major conferences.

This project has generated three journal publications, three conference publications, one doctoral dissertation, and one master’s thesis. Two Ph.D. students and two M.S. students partially supported by this project have successfully graduated. The two Ph.D. students both won the Dean's Award for Outstanding Scholarship at Michigan Technological University (MTU). Another four Ph.D. students were trained in this project with multidisciplinary skills. A number of undergraduate students have been involved in this research project to gain research experience. In addition, this project has provided equal research opportunities to students, especially for those from underrepresented groups.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2024
Modified by: Ye Sun
